BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 4, 1921
CONCERNING THE PRINCETON CONFERENCE
The conference at Princeton University on the limitation of
armaments questions was undoubtedly productive of good intentions
and also of certain good results, though the latter may seem somewhat intangible. To the everyday college undergraduate, the seriousness of such a question as armament limitation forces him to relegate it to that group of subjects which he knows he should be interested in, but which he rather automatically steers clear of. It is
rather a characteristic thing among American college students—this
manifest disinterest and almost utter apathy regarding the more
profound issues of the day.
It must have been this tendency which prompted President
Hibben of Princeton University to conceive this idea of a conference
for the discussion of the disarmament question. With the date of
Hibben
the Washington Conference looming near at hand, Dr.
grasped this opportunity of bringing this all-important issue before
colthe thought of each undergraduate student in our Eastern
leges. Again there might be a pressure brought to bear on branches
of public opinion other than the student thought.
Before the conference took place word went out from Princeton
that it was not the purpose or hope of the conference to exercise any
influence at the larger conference in Washington. The intention
of this meeting at Princeton was to• arouse interest and stimulate
discussion among college students of the disarmament question. We
may say that it has accomplished pretty well that which it strove to
bring about. The response and interest which has been aroused is
an excellent thing. Why should the men who will probably have to
bear the brunt of future wars remain quiet and think disinterestedly
on this subject? It is to be hoped that the considerate thought of
every Hopkins student is given over to the possible settlement of
this menace. It is a very adequate way of showing appreciation for
those in Flanders Field.

THE POST-SEASON GAME
It is with great pleasure that we learn of the possibility of a postseason football game with the University of Florida. Some of the
older students may remember that the News-Letter advocated closer
athletic relations with Southern colleges in its editorial column last
spring, and the opportunities which Florida's proposition opens in
this field are well worthy of consideration.
We would like on this occasion to repeat our belief that Hopkins
future rests with the Southern -rather than the Northern colleges;
that, with the acquisition of dormitories, the majority of out-of-town
students will come from South of the Mason-Dixon Line; and that
anything which will strengthen our relations with the colleges in
this region will be to our advantage.
Our relations with this University have been most cordial, and
we believe that a mutual respect for both institutions has
been instilled in the student bodies. We have not felt this same re
spect for some other colleges. The game with Florida, if consum
mated, would give us an additional opportunity to experience what
we are sure will prove to be true Southern hospitality. Let us hope
that it will prove to be a forerunner of our closer athletic relations
with the South.

ATHLETIC GOSSIP
Such an inter-sectional clash as
the proposed Johns Hopkins-University of Florida game will attract
as much if not more attention than
the Georgia-Penn State game, as it
is a post-season game and will
monopolize the pigskin chatter on
the sport pages. We'll get a lot of
advertising in out-of-town papers,
even if our own city's pages fail to
give us the proper amount of support.

ZIONIST SOCIETY HOLDS SMOKER

The Zionist Society held its
smoker last Sunday at 3 P. M. at
the Chizuk Amuno Synagogue
(McCulloh and Mosher streets).
About fifty persons were present.
The Rev. Dr. Coblenz addressed
those present on the subject of
"The International Jew." The out-

BONDS

standing issues of the speech
were: the importance of the Jew
to modern civilization; and his
part in the civilization of the
world. He also narrated the history of the Jews.
After the address a discussion
was held by the members. Many
questions
were
interesting
brought up and answered, in turn,
by Dr. Coblenz.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 4, 1921
CONCERNING THE PRINCETON CONFERENCE
The conference at Princeton University on the limitation of
armaments questions was undoubtedly productive of good intentions
and also of certain good results, though the latter may seem somewhat intangible. To the everyday college undergraduate, the seriousness of such a question as armament limitation forces him to relegate it to that group of subjects which he knows he should be interested in, but which he rather automatically steers clear of. It is
rather a characteristic thing among American college students—this
manifest disinterest and almost utter apathy regarding the more
profound issues of the day.
It must have been this tendency which prompted President
Hibben of Princeton University to conceive this idea of a conference
for the discussion of the disarmament question. With the date of
Hibben
the Washington Conference looming near at hand, Dr.
grasped this opportunity of bringing this all-important issue before
colthe thought of each undergraduate student in our Eastern
leges. Again there might be a pressure brought to bear on branches
of public opinion other than the student thought.
Before the conference took place word went out from Princeton
that it was not the purpose or hope of the conference to exercise any
influence at the larger conference in Washington. The intention
of this meeting at Princeton was to• arouse interest and stimulate
discussion among college students of the disarmament question. We
may say that it has accomplished pretty well that which it strove to
bring about. The response and interest which has been aroused is
an excellent thing. Why should the men who will probably have to
bear the brunt of future wars remain quiet and think disinterestedly
on this subject? It is to be hoped that the considerate thought of
every Hopkins student is given over to the possible settlement of
this menace. It is a very adequate way of showing appreciation for
those in Flanders Field.

THE POST-SEASON GAME
It is with great pleasure that we learn of the possibility of a postseason football game with the University of Florida. Some of the
older students may remember that the News-Letter advocated closer
athletic relations with Southern colleges in its editorial column last
spring, and the opportunities which Florida's proposition opens in
this field are well worthy of consideration.
We would like on this occasion to repeat our belief that Hopkins
future rests with the Southern -rather than the Northern colleges;
that, with the acquisition of dormitories, the majority of out-of-town
students will come from South of the Mason-Dixon Line; and that
anything which will strengthen our relations with the colleges in
this region will be to our advantage.
Our relations with this University have been most cordial, and
we believe that a mutual respect for both institutions has
been instilled in the student bodies. We have not felt this same re
spect for some other colleges. The game with Florida, if consum
mated, would give us an additional opportunity to experience what
we are sure will prove to be true Southern hospitality. Let us hope
that it will prove to be a forerunner of our closer athletic relations
with the South.

most perfect packing science can devise to protect cigarettes and keep them fresh. Heavy

to seal the fold and make the package air-tight.
But there's nothing flashy about it. You'll find
no extra wrappers. No frills or furbelows.
Such things do not improve the smoke any
more than premiums or coupons. And remember
—you must pay their extra cost or get lowered
quality.
If you want the smoothest, mellowest, mildest
cigarette you can imagine—and one entirely free
from cigaretty aftertaste,
It's Camels- for you.

Litt. D., chairman of the Department of Modern Languages in
Princeton University, and vicepresident of the Dante Society of
America, gave a lecture on Dante
in the Civil Engineering building

19 W. LEXINGTON ST.
ZIONIST SOCIETY HOLDS SMOKER

The Zionist Society held its
smoker last Sunday at 3 P. M. at
the Chizuk Amuno Synagogue
(McCulloh and Mosher streets).
About fifty persons were present.
The Rev. Dr. Coblenz addressed
those present on the subject of
"The International Jew." The out-

BONDS

standing issues of the speech
were: the importance of the Jew
to modern civilization; and his
part in the civilization of the
world. He also narrated the history of the Jews.
After the address a discussion
was held by the members. Many
questions
were
interesting
brought up and answered, in turn,
by Dr. Coblenz.
